description: From Middle English pome (“fruit, meatball”), from Old French pome (“apple”), from Latin pōmum. For the verb, compare French pommer. Doublet of pomme.

entries.meaning: (botany) A type of fruit in which the often edible flesh arises from the swollen base of the flower and not from the carpels.
examples: The best-known example of a pome is the apple.

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) A ball of silver or other metal, filled with hot water and used by a Roman Catholic priest in cold weather to warm his hands during the service.
Alternative form of pomme (“green roundel in heraldry”)

verbs.description: pome (third-person singular simple present pomes, present participle poming, simple past and past participle pomed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To grow to a head, or form a head in growing.
